caption:
Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Roxane Gay,  photographed in Los Angeles, August 21, 2018. Roxane Gay is a writer, professor, editor, and commentator. In anticipation of the 100th anniversary of the 19th amendment, National Geographic is highlighting what it means to be female. As part of that coverage, we photographed luminaries from around the world.

Check out the link in our bio to learn about Nat Geo’s groundbreaking new book that showcases an incredible group of history-making women. #NatGeoWomenofImpact

Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder // Sponsored by @MazdaUSA #NatGeoMazdaContest // An Indonesian girl rides a pink bicycle matching her vibrant head scarf through Fatahillah Square in Jakarta, where she and her family traveled during the holy month of Ramadan to visit relatives and celebrate Eid al-Fitr. Fatahillah Square is a historic area in what was once the heart of Dutch colonial rule. I enjoyed watching the plaza fill with families who rented brightly colored bicycles and floral hats, laughed while circling the square together, and took pictures to remember the festivities. // Enter the #NatGeoMazdaContest to win the opportunity to be one of National Geographic’s next great storytellers. When you are out with your camera, what remarkable or impactful moments have you captured? We want to see what inspires you. Upload a gallery of 3-5 images to your Instagram account as one post, with the hashtag #NatGeoMazdaContest, tagging @natgeoyourshot. The contest, presented by @MazdaUSA, runs through November 18, 2019. Open to legal residents of the 50 U.S./D.C. only; 18+. For more information go to natgeo.com/mazdacontest.
labels: ['Bicycle', 'Pink', 'Bicycle wheel', 'Vehicle', 'Cycling', 'Bicycle drivetrain part', 'Snapshot', 'Mode of transport', 'Recreation', 'Sports equipment']

caption: Photo by George Steinmetz @geosteinmetz | A camel caravan crosses the Ténéré Desert of Niger with loads of salt for distribution to markets across West Africa. I took this picture in 1997 from my "paramotor," which provided a new perspective on this ancient trade route. It was a year of good rains, and that made for an unusually large number of camels healthy enough for the two-month-long round trip to the oasis of Bilma. To explore more of our world from above, follow @geosteinmetz.

Photo by Maggie Steber @maggiesteber | Veteran forensic artist Jeanne Boylan recovers fragmented impressions of shapes and textures etched deep in memory by trauma in victims of crimes. She has helped solve some of the most notorious crimes of past decades. She says her crucial skill is not drawing but simply listening, often for hours. “Witnesses often surprise themselves,” she says, “with what they remember when someone is willing to listen.” She comes in after witnesses have often been questioned for hours by police trying to ascertain details of a crime. She asks subjects about color, temperature, and other small details. From this information, she draws a likeness of the criminal. One of her most famous drawings helped the FBI identify and catch the Unabomber in April 1996, ending a 17-year chase. #natgeowomenofvision #memory #women

Photo by Anastasia Taylor-Lind @anastasiatl | Night nurse Tamiesha Graham Baker shows new mom Kelly Howell a feeding technique to try with baby Rooney in Long Island, New York. Before work Baker says good night to her own 10-year-old daughter, Nyiesha, who stays with an aunt until morning.
I spent five months embedded with New York City families, documenting the brutal math of caring for children in America.

Photo by Sara Hylton @sarahyltonphoto | A mother and her child at an Afghan refugee settlement, on the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan, pause from their daily duties. This image was made in July 2018, in the lead-up to the federal elections. Newly elected Prime Minister Imran Khan promised to grant citizenship to Afghan refugees, but over a year later, citizenship is still off the table. For more stories follow me @sarahyltonphoto #refugees #Afghanistan #Pakistan

Photo by Dina Litovsky @dina_litovsky | Shouq Faisal Madani, from Saudi Arabia, celebrates with her team at the Grand Awards Ceremony at the 2019 International Science and Engineering Fair. While historically female attendance at science fairs has been low, this year’s event was evenly split by gender, and three of the top awards went to young women. 
This story about girls in science is in National Geographic’s November issue. For more images follow me @dina_litovsky.

Photo by Lynsey Addario @lynseyaddario | Deyraliz Perez Gines, 25, of Bayamon, Puerto Rico, is reprimanded by her drill instructor at Parris Island, S.C.—the only place in the country where women train to become Marines. For the next 11 weeks, they would speak only in the third person, calling themselves “this recruit” instead of “I” to absolve all individuality. Today, women make up eight percent of the United States Marine Corps. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.

Photos by Pete McBride @pedromcbride | Layers of mountain light—and wildfire smoke. Decades of wildland management that focused on fire suppression have played a hand in the increasing wildfire devastation we’re seeing, including California’s deadliest wildfire on record last year. A changing climate also plays a role, by bringing hotter and drier weather patterns, enabling bigger and harder-to-control infernos and increasing fire danger from the U.S. West to the Southeast. Last summer, I nearly lost my Colorado hometown to a wildfire as I watched (and photographed, second image) in a panic while evacuating. Not all are so lucky. Now I view these hazy sunsets with awe, knowing this natural cycle is important. But I also observe with apprehension, fearful of the outcome. For more on our natural world, follow @pedromcbride. #wildfire #nature #light

Photos by Richard Barnes @richardbarnes | Can the remarkable architecture built by monstrous leaders redeem their reputations? Nero, emperor of ancient Rome, was known for killing two of his wives, allegedly killing his mother, crucifying Christians, and ordering the stoic philosopher Seneca to commit suicide. Nero was emperor when Rome burned in 64 C.E. His legacy lives on in the ambitious architectures he built, such as the Colosseum and his palace, the Domus Aurea (Golden House). It is thought that Villa Oplontis was owned by Nero and used as his second wife’s residence; its colorful frescoes have been remarkably preserved. Some say he was an avant-garde artist and visionary, his brutality simply a product of his time. Other historians define him by his obsession with popularity, and his desire for a godlike authority. Known as a public relations master, he embraced spectacle and performance on a grand scale. Follow @richardbarnes for more. #richardbarnes #nero #rome #emperors

Photo by Ian Teh @iantehphotography | I recently reviewed my photographs of China’s coal industry from 2006 to 2010 in prep for a presentation to a Nat Geo Student Expedition in Beijing. I took this photo when China was building two coal power stations a week. Today the country is set to add a further 25% to its capacity. If this extra capacity becomes operational, it would make it much more difficult for the world to limit CO2 emissions. Despite China being a global frontrunner in investing in alternative energy, this would be a major setback, according to advocates. In a BBC report last year, researchers suggested that these plants have more to do with boosting the local economies in China rather than providing any energy needs. #china #coal #climatechange #gloabalwarming #industrialisation
Photo by Tasneem Alsultan @tasneemalsultan | A teenager uses Rollerblades in front of the King Fahad National Library in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. #riyadh #saudiarabia

Photo by Beverly Joubert @beverlyjoubert | Few cats like to get their feet wet, and lions are no exception. If, however, you happen to live in the Okavango Delta and you're a pride's male patrolling a territory, keeping paws and other parts dry is a definite challenge. When the delta's waters are high, these cats will need to swim across deep channels, despite their aversion. The drier months offer some respite, but those swimming muscles can come in handy when there's a channel that can be navigated with a giant leap. #thisismytrophy #okavangolions #bigcats

Photo by Diana Markosian @markosian | Sulin, 8, floats on her back in a pool in Wolfsburg, Germany. Sulin and her family arrived in Germany from Iraq as part of the migration wave in 2016. A year later, she started swimming courses as a way of allowing her to overcome the trauma she faced on the journey.

Photo by Stephen Wilkes @stephenwilkes | Photographing this glacier from a plane at 20,000 feet over Greenland, we can see it beginning to melt, the circular ring of clear blue water creating a mirror image of the sun itself. To see more photos from my travels near and far, follow me @stephenwilkes.  #StephenWilkes #Glacier #Greenland #Aerial #ClimateChange

Photo by John Stanmeyer @johnstanmeyer | Today is World Tsunami Awareness Day. Haystack rock is located right off the beach in Cannon Beach, Oregon. Paleotsunami scientists say a future tsunami could hit here at any time. Cannon Beach is heavily populated with businesses and expensive homes laying in tsunami evacuation zones.

Photo by Jimmy Chin @jimmychin | The act of climbing mountains is often misunderstood. It can mean different things to different people. The reasons can be deeply personal, or about sharing an incredible experience with your climbing partners. For some it becomes a meditation in being present. Life stripped to the basics—movement through the landscape with purpose. At its most raw, it can be about survival.⁠ Conrad Anker has made a career seeking out, exploring, and climbing some of the most remote unclimbed walls in the world. Beyond climbing, he has been a mentor to new generations of climbers, and also worked to protect the wild landscapes he loves. But at the end of the day, he still loves climbing. Here in minus 20°F temps, he ascends a new 4000-foot route on Ulvetanna, aka the Wolf’s Fang, in Antarctica. Ask him why he’d spend a week on a wall in subzero temps and he might not be able to tell you...but he was surely present and enjoying this moment. For more images from mountain adventures around the world, follow @jimmychin

Photos by John Stanmeyer @johnstanmeyer | Today is World Tsunami Awareness Day. After witnessing the enormity of what occurred on December 26, 2004, I was extremely affected. Having documented for decades the effects of war, conflict, and human indifference to why we can’t get along, there is always “someone to blame“ in these situations. With natural disasters that have occurred throughout Earth’s existence, when I asked those who survived how they felt or what could have been done, their universal response was “Who should I blame, God?” This reality deeply affected me, and I needed to understand how both the Earth, and humanity, heals. So began this multiyear, multidecade project of revisiting the exact spots where the earth had done its natural movements.

Upon returning one year later, the changes were profound, as seen here in the second photo. Returning four years later, I could barely find signs that a massive wall of water, more than 100 feet high, had ever existed. Thousands of new people had taken up residence, trees and plants had grown again in abundance. The landscape and those who now inhabited this area of Sumatra have changed.

Yes, the people to this day in Indonesia are still deeply affected by the enormity that took place on Boxing Day 2004, and the earth had healed beyond recognition, a reminder that the Earth doesn’t need us.

Photos by Babak Tafreshi @babaktafreshi | Deep in the night sky, a dark snake is hidden beyond our visual limits. Look for the S-shaped dust lane on the left, in front of the Milky Way star clouds. Swipe to zoom out and see wider angle views of this area. The tiny dark nebula known as the Snake is one of my favorite gems in the night sky. I recently photographed it next to the dazzling light of Jupiter. The Snake is like other interstellar clouds, mainly made of hydrogen, but with more dust particles and dense enough to block the light of stars behind. The Snake is little but easy to reveal in this single one-minute exposure through a telephoto lens on a small star-tracking mount. The big dark nebula in the second slide is known as the Pipe, visible to unaided eyes in a dark sky. ⁣Follow me @babaktafreshi for more of astronomy and space photography. #astrophotography #astronomy #milkyway #saveournightsky

Photo by Drew Rush @drewtrush | While we were in Yellowstone National Park this summer, we had a chance to look for wildlife every day. Catching the sunrise as you watch a group of bull elk feed is something you'll never forget—no matter how many times you may be fortunate enough to see it. Shot while on a student trip with @natgeoexpedtions. To see more wildlife images, follow along with photographer @drewtrush.

Photo by Ivan Kashinsky @ivankphoto | A man walks on the Salar de Uyuni, in Bolivia, the world’s largest salt flat. This photo was part of book project in which Karla Gachet and I traveled from the Equator to the southern tip of South America.

Photo by Gabriele Galimberti @gabrielegalimbertiphoto and Juri De Luca | Fossils of long-extinct creatures aren’t just for museums. Today they’re in homes and businesses, as wealthy collectors indulge a controversial hobby. At the Hanging Gardens of Marqueyssac in France, communications officer Stéphanie Angleys cleans the display case of a 150-million-year-old Allosaurus. Owned by French businessman Kléber Rossillon, the gardens are open to the public. Rossillon acquired the dinosaur—whose skull is among the best preserved in the world—in 2016, a few years after it was found in Wyoming. #dinosaur #fossil #extinct #dinosaurs

Photo by Brian Skerry @brianskerry | A study in the morphology of the oceanic whitetip shark. Living in the pelagic zone (open ocean), oceanic whitetips are shaped like aircrafts, with long pectoral fins that allow them to glide efficiently over long distances, expending little energy. 
In 2006, I led a trip to Cat Island in The Bahamas, where we discovered a population of this species in one of the few locations left where these animals predictably can be found. Oceanic whitetip populations have been decimated due to the demand for their fins, which are prized for shark fin soup. Like the American bison, an animal that was once abundant and then hunted to the brink, only a fraction of oceanic whitetip shark populations remains today. Their numbers declined 93% between 1995 and 2010. Recovery will be difficult, because they reach sexual maturity by age seven and have small litters of pups every one to two years. To learn more about sharks and other ocean animals, follow @BrianSkerry. #oceanicwhitetip #sharks #Bahamas

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Beneath a starry sky,  a puff of pink smoke rises from Stromboli. Near the mount's  base, the headlights of the last few tourist groups coming down the volcano's slope can be seen approaching the village of Stromboli, located on the coast. Every evening, tour groups hike up to the rim of the crater to watch small but energetic explosive eruptions of ash, lava, and stone blocks. Such eruptions are known as Strombolian eruptions—which occur on volcanoes throughout the world.
Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | A herd of elephants gather under a mophane tree at sunrise, northern Botswana.

Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | // Supported by Nat Geo Society/Wyss Campaign for Nature committed to protecting 30% of the planet by 2030. // A young Thomson's gazelle leaps across the plains of Kenya's Maasai Mara at sunset. The gazelle was grazing among a herd of zebra and topi when it decided to stretch its legs by running at high speed for a few minutes. Thomson's gazelles are one of the world's fastest land animals, able to hit speeds of 55 miles per hour. They need to be fast: they're a favorite prey of cheetahs. So running and leaping like this might perhaps be a valuable activity, designed to keep them fit and practicing weaving and dodging—which could save a tommie's life one day. #campaignfornature

Photo by Amber Bracken @photobracken | "It was always hard to stand in prayer," Chief Arvol Looking Horse said of Standing Rock. He spoke of a dishonorable war that was prophesied during the time of the black snake, widely interpreted to be the Dakota Access Pipeline, and during the camps, when teargas, pepper spray, rubber bullets, and attack dogs were deployed against nonviolent "water protectors." Chief Looking Horse is the founder of World Peace and Prayer Day, held on June 21 since 1996, and after Standing Rock has continued to be a leading voice speaking for climate action, native rights, and peace. He speaks for a deepened and restored relationship to ceremony, pointing out that the traditional Lakota, Nakota, and Dakota way of life is inherently in balance with the natural world. #StandingRock #ClimateAction #peace

Photo by William Albert Allard @williamalbertallard | Cow Horse in the Snow, Padlock Ranch, Montana, 1978

This is a favorite horse portrait, made during calving season in Montana. The horse was used by ranch hands watching over first-calf heifers in a nearby pasture. When a heifer seemed ready to give birth, a cowboy would drive her into a fenced area; when the calf dropped, he’d bring it into the calving barn with a sled, tied by rope to the cowboy’s saddle. This horse was left waiting to be used, standing outside the shed where the cowboys would warm themselves and drink endless cups of coffee. For more images of the American West and other assignments spanning a five-decade career #followme @williamalbertallard. @thephotosociety #montana #ranch #horse #snow

Photo by Michael Yamashita @yamashitaphoto | High above the western Himalaya—this massive mountain range contains some of the highest peaks on Earth. It covers around 1,500 miles, through the nations of India, Pakistan, Afghanistan, China, Bhutan, and Nepal. #himalayanmountains #himalaya #himalayan

Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder | Two donkeys rest in the shade of a building on Main Street in the Route 66 town of Oatman, Arizona. We’ve been crossing the country, making a classic U.S-style road trip. But we’re also driving electric cars, visiting renewable energy projects, and meeting people with innovative ideas about energy to see where we are, where we need to be and how to get to a renewable energy future. On assignment for @natgeo on a #roadtripto2070

Photo by Maddie McGarvey @maddiemcgarvey | Aubrey, the Jr. Miss Indian Oklahoma City, and Isabel, Little Miss Indian Oklahoma City, are seen at a powwow in Carnegie. For more views from around the country, follow me @maddiemcgarvey.

Photo by Simon Norfolk @simonnorfolkstudio I This scene is on the tiny island of Hamnøy, connected by bridge to Moskenesøya, part of the Lofoten Islands in Arctic Norway. Stockfish is unsalted fish, especially cod, dried by cold air and wind on wooden racks called hjell. The drying of food is the world's oldest known preservation method, and dried fish has a storage life of several years. Due to the stable, cold conditions, the stockfish produced on the Lofoten Islands is regarded as the best. Stockfish is Norway's longest sustained export commodity, first mentioned in the Icelandic saga "Egilssaga," when Chief Torolv Kveldulvssøn shipped stockfish from Helgeland in Norway to Britain in 875. This product represented most of Norway's national income from the Viking age through to the medieval period.
Many of the cod heads are bought by the Norwegian government and given away as Norway's food aid to areas of crisis in the developing world. Follow @simonnorfolkstudio for updates, outtakes, unpublished, and archive material. #norway #arctic #norgefoto #norgesfoto #Nordland

Photo by Acacia Johnson @acacia.johnson | Joy and Amelia, age 10, don heart-shaped glasses for a Friday night dance in Arctic Bay, Nunavut, a remote Inuit community on Canada's Baffin Island. The Inuit place high value on community and cultivate strong social networks, a remnant of an age-old sharing economy that enabled them to survive their harsh environment for thousands of years. During the winter, when temperatures average around -30°F, social events such as weekly dances, sports, and feasts are important for community well-being—and simply enjoying life during three months of winter darkness. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from the Arctic and beyond! #nunavut #inuit #baffinisland

Photo by Stephen Alvarez @salvarezphoto | National forestland, Utah. This "circle of friends" pictograph is a Barrier Canyon Style painting that depicts 17 anthropomorphic figures holding hands and arranged around a circle at their feet. Rock art like this panel is notoriously hard to date, but Barrier Canyon Style paintings are thought to be somewhere in the 1,500- to 4,000-year-old range. For most of human history our important stories were recorded as pictures on rock and cave walls. I started my nonprofit @ancientartarchive to preserve and share those stories—because like this image, I think they help bring us together.

Photos by David Liitschwager @davidliittschwager | Happy World Jellyfish Day! This is an upside-down jellyfish (scientific name: Cassiopea xamachana). These jellyfish are usually found resting on the shallow ocean floor with their frilly oral arms facing up. They have a symbiotic relationship with the algae that live in their tissues. By exposing their underside to the sun, the jellyfish allow the algae to photosynthesize. The jellyfish live off the food that the algae produces as well as eat plankton. This is a similar relationship to zooxanthellae found in the tissues of coral. 
Photographed on assignment for National Geographic at the Elizabeth Moore International Center for Coral Reef Research & Restoration in the Florida Keys. @natgeoimagecollection @thephotosociety #WorldJellyfishDay

Photo by Nora Lorek @noralorek | Jesca Ropan lost her 3-year-old daughter Hellen when fleeing South Sudan for Uganda. ”When my neighbor was killed, I took my two children and started to walk towards the border. We didn’t have any clean water or food, and on the second day Hellen died. I was devastated and wanted to go back but I knew I had to continue for my family.” Jesca, here shown with her son Hammond, is the women’s representative for her village in Bidibidi refugee settlement and works as a caregiver at her children’s school. Four years ago the area containing Bidibidi was a forest in northwestern Uganda. Now it’s a makeshift home for a quarter million refugees who fled the civil war in South Sudan.

Photo by Thomas Peschak @thomaspeschak | I love islands, and the more off the beaten track they are, the better. Masirah Island sits in the Arabian Sea, 20 km off the coast of Oman, and it's a place where I have very fond memories. Its friendly and hospitable people, the "free range" camels roaming the streets, and one of the densest and most important loggerhead nesting grounds in the world are still forever imprinted on my mind. On an early morning beach patrol, we came across a female loggerhead turtle returning to the ocean after nesting. I crouched and waded into the surf zone to make this image, just before she dived under a wave and disappeared into her ocean home. For more photographs from some of the world’s wildest islands follow @thomaspeschak.

caption: Photo by Karla Gachet @kchete77 | Adela Choquetiglla and daughter Maribel Chambi comb their hair at home in Colchani, Bolivia. They are Aymara, one of the indigenous cultures in the Andes. The town is near the Salar de Uyuni, the world's largest salt flats, where most of the salt in Bolivia originates. According to Aymaran tradition, the mountains used to be giants that walked the Earth; Tunupa, Kusku, and Kusina were mountains surrounding the Salar. Tunupa married Kusku, who ran away with Kusina. Tunupa cried while breastfeeding her son, and her tears mixed with her milk, forming the Salar. Some Aymarans consider Tunupa a deity and say that the place should be called Salar de Tunupa. #andesmagic #aymaraculture

Photo by Simon Roberts @simoncroberts | Namsan Park, on Mount Namsan, is the largest park in Seoul, South Korea. Each day, it draws thousands of people looking for a slice of nature in the middle of the city. During the rule of Taejo, the first king of the Joseon Dynasty, Namsan (south mountain) was considered a sacred shamanistic site. Today it offers wooded paths, cherry blossom trails, and some of the most spectacular views of downtown Seoul. #NamsanPark #UrbanParks #Seoul #MountNamsan

Photo by Jodi Cobb @jodicobbphoto | As the first and only woman staff field photographer at National Geographic, I was inevitably defined as a “woman photographer,” as if gender alone would explain my motivations, vision, and desires. I fought that label; it seemed like an extra job to do. I felt a burden to be perfect, capable of doing all the things the men could do. 
But I eventually realized that being a woman was the best thing about my life. I was welcomed into the hidden worlds of women that had never been photographed before, especially those at the edge of change, facing cultural dislocation from war, poverty, and human trafficking. I’ve explored the complexities of their lives, searching for the moments that reveal how they prevail or just survive. I’ve found women defiant, triumphant, or simply making the best of it. But the women who’ve inspired and humbled me the most are those enduring the most brutal circumstances and somehow surviving, against all odds. Here, women in debt bondage in India work in the brick kilns, bearing astonishing burdens all day, every day. Follow me @jodicobbphoto for more images of women and the world. #humantrafficking

caption: Photo by William Daniels @williamodaniels | Near Sugula, in southern Mali, a group carries basins of maize cobs on their heads. In 2009, I travelled for a week in the region to photograph countryside schools for a project on education. In crowded rooms, I met children excited to attend but also those who can’t because they have to work with their parents. Sometimes I even photographed adults outside a school as they listened to the teacher through a window. Wherever I am in the world, I love visiting schools— they tell us so much about the societies we are visiting. Follow me on @williamodaniels for more human stories around the world.

Photo by Rena Effendi @renaeffendiphoto | I met Sister Angelique in the Democratic Republic of Congo while working on a story about the survivors of violence perpetrated by the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels and how they coped with the trauma of war. Sister Angelique was a local nun in Dungu who sheltered orphans born out of sexual violence—children of women who were abducted by the LRA rebels. I was in awe of her grace and power. For more human interest stories #followme @renaeffendiphoto #women #power #beauty #war

Photo by Michaela Skovranova @mishkusk | National Geographic explorer Emma Camp collects coral samples for transplants on the Great Barrier Reef. 
Camp's research and her discovery of resilient coral hot spots have been fundamental for the recently published Future Reefs project, one of the first coral transplant projects on the Great Barrier Reef. While working in the field, the team often faces challenging conditions—despite the rough weather, poor visibility, and high winds, the team pushed on with their tasks. Emma's experience, positive energy, and warmth are much needed in times like these. #womeninstem #thegreatbarrierreef #futurereefprogram

Photo by Michael Christopher Brown @michaelchristopherbrown | Simon, a recent Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) defector, waited at a Uganda People's Defence Force and U.S. Special Forces base in Obo, Central African Republic, in March 2014. His brother, also a LRA combatant, was due to defect that day. Most days of the week, pilots transported U.S. Special Forces and supplies from Uganda to South Sudan, Democratic Republic of the Congo, and the Central African Republic to support a coalition that included African militaries to help counter the LRA, led by the fugitive Joseph Kony. Though Kony was not captured, the $780 million operation largely came to an end in 2017 as “the operation has essentially taken that group off the battlefield,” said American General Thomas Waldhauser. Since then, armed groups have carried out attacks on previously protected communities, often targeting people based on their religious, ethnic, or livelihood identity. The LRA killed an estimated 100,000-plus people and kidnapped 60,000 children in a three-decade-long rebellion spanning northern Uganda, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Democratic Republic of Congo. For more follow @michaelchristopherbrown

Photo by Katie Orlinsky @katieorlinsky | A snow fence in Utqiagvik, Alaska, is meant to provide protection from the threat of winter storms that can engulf the entire village in snow drifts. Extreme weather events are becoming increasingly common, as warming weather and melting sea ice transform the Arctic’s climate. Meanwhile, building this kind of necessary infrastructure is challenged by shifting ground caused by thawing permafrost.

Photo by Nichole Sobecki @nicholesobecki | This summer I spent time in the Kyangwali refugee settlement, where serious violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo has led thousands to seek safety in southwestern Uganda. In this overcrowded maternity ward in the settlement, women giving birth were forced to share beds. Watching them pressing together through labor pains and cooing and sharing advice as they nursed, I was overwhelmed by the glow of fellowship among these strangers—these women—brought together by crisis and new life. #uganda #drc #women #birth

Photo by Trevor Frost @tbfrost | A juvenile Amazon tree boa rests in the hands of Lucas Bustamante, an Ecuadorian scientist and photographer who helps run the nonprofit @tropicalherping. Tropical Herping conducts scientific surveys of unexplored areas and also works to protect the Ecuadorian Choco region, a little known and highly imperiled swath of tropical forest that runs along the Pacific coast of South America, from Ecuador to Panama. This boa is sometimes referred to as the Halloween boa because of its orange and black coloring. If you want to see more of the world's snake species, head over to @tbfrost.

Photo by Paul Nicklen @paulnicklen | Aleqatsiaq Peary is the great-great-great grandson of Sir Robert Peary, a man who claimed to have reached the North Pole on expedition as far back as 1909. One of the great challenges early Arctic explorers faced was navigating their ships, which would often freeze, through fields of sea ice. Hunters across the Arctic today suffer the opposite fate: the sea ice is rapidly disappearing. Climate change threatens thousands of years of tradition. Just like polar bears, Inuit need the ice in order to travel and hunt. The world is changing, and changing fast. Is it possible that the prospect of shorter shipping trade routes opening up in the Arctic as the ice disappears is one of the reasons why some governments refuse to acknowledge the climate crisis? Please follow me @PaulNicklen for more of my personal stories from the front lines of the #climatecrisis. #portrait #Greenland #WeAreIndigenous #ClimateChangeIsReal

Photo by Mattias Klum @mattiasklumofficial | I photographed this Jameson's mamba killing a fledgling in Cameroon. Like other mambas, the venom of the Jameson's mamba is highly neurotoxic. It also includes cardiotoxins and fasciculins, and may also have hemotoxic and myotoxic components. A bite from Jameson's mamba can be deadly in as little as 30 to 120 minutes without proper medical treatment. Ironically it is the lethal characteristics of snake venom that make it so valuable and sought after for use in medicinal treatments. The toxic components of snake venom have, for example, led to the development of medicine for heart disease, diabetes, and Alzheimer's. With a bit of luck, the Jameson’s mamba may soon combat heart disease—and  without hurting the snakes: Just a blood sample from one individual snake in the rain forest, and the snake was free to slither away. Please go to @mattiasklumofficial for more images from our film and photo projects around the world. #greenmamba #protectbiodiversity #science #zoltantakacs

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | Last July marked the hottest month on record since temperature records began, as heat waves hit many parts of the world. I captured this image on the July 22, while flying over the Dead Sea in Jordan. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic #muhammedmuheisen #deadsea #Jordan

Photo by Becky Hale @beckythale | Marine explorer Katy Croff Bell was gracious enough to spend 20 minutes partially submerged in a (not very warm) kiddie pool in her wet suit for this photograph. It’s always such an honor to photograph some of the amazing women who walk through the doors of National Geographic's headquarters in Washington, D.C.

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | The spiderweb wires and architecture of the Brooklyn Bridge are a widely known icon of New York City. The bridge is one of the oldest roadway bridges in the U.S., opening to the public in 1883, and designed by architect John A. Roebling. It spans the East River and was originally designed for commuters riding on horse and carriage, bicycles and on foot. It was the first bridge constructed using steel wire.

Photo by Joel Sartore @joelsartore | These Panamanian golden frogs are Panama's national symbol, one that dates back to the age of Mayan civilization. Pictured on everything from T-shirts to lottery tickets to magazines, the tiny frog represents good fortune, though its own fortunes have not gone well. Learn why by following me @joelsartore. Photo taken @houstonzoo. #goldenfrog #Panama #goodfortune #PhotoArk

Photo by Simon Norfolk @simonnorfolkstudio I The United Kingdom's largest rock salt (halite) mine is in northwest England, at Winsford, in Cheshire. It is one of only three places where rock salt is commercially mined in the U.K., the others being in North Yorkshire and Northern Ireland. Rock salt extraction began at Winsford in the 17th century. Initially it was used as salt licks for animals and to strengthen weak brine. In 1844 Winsford Rock Salt Mine was opened, and is claimed by its operator, Salt Union Ltd., to be Britain's oldest working mine. Seen here is Avenue One, a main roadway through the vast mine. The walled-in cavern on the left is part of DeepStore, which is devoted to document storage. Follow @simonnorfolkstudio for updates, outtakes, unpublished, and archive material. #saltmine #underground #deepstore #Winsford #mining

Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames I // Supported by Nat Geo Society/Wyss Campaign for Nature committed to protecting 30% of the planet by 2030. // At dawn this morning in the Maasai Mara National Reserve, two male lions guard their kill. The brothers, known locally as Flappy Left Ear and Junk Left Ear, killed the large eland the day before yesterday and have been feeding on it since. They take turns leaving its side to drink or sleep, but one always guards it from the hungry vultures and hyenas that remain ever present. #campaignfornature

Photo by Beverly Joubert @beverlyjoubert | These are bull elephants. They tend to keep to themselves for many months and occasionally form small bachelor groups, as they wander the dry lands in the rain shadow of Kilimanjaro that the matriarchal herds avoid. They'll join up with the herds periodically, but an older bull tends to like his space. Thirst is what brings the animals together here, and these bulls will meet regularly for a social catch-up around a water hole. It's easy to see who knows whom intricately, which animals are old friends, and who is perhaps slightly out of favor. There's something remarkably familiar about it all. 
#ThejoyofElephants #ThisisMyTrophy #ChyuluHills #olDonyo

caption: Photo by George Steinmetz @geosteinmetz | Harvesting wheat on China’s Loess Plateau, in Ningxia, is still a family affair. The fine silty soil was deposited by desert winds over thousands of years, and then carved into terraces for agriculture. Farming here is increasingly difficult as children migrate to the cities for higher paying jobs. With a small amount of arable land per capita, China struggles to feed itself. To explore more of our world from above, follow @geosteinemtz.

Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder // Sponsored by @MazdaUSA #NatGeoMazdaContest // A Cuban man and young boy play basketball together against the outer wall of their home along the Malecón, a seafront esplanade in Havana. I went to photograph the Malecón because it is a picturesque place of warm light, cruising classic American cars, and the melancholy beauty of crumbling and grand architecture. But the Malecón is also where I first met the people who would share their stories with me and generously offer a glimpse into the realities of life in Cuba today. // When you are out with your camera, what remarkable or impactful moments have you captured? We want to see what inspires you. Upload a gallery of 3-5 images to your Instagram account with the hashtag #NatGeoMazdaContest, tagging @natgeoyourshot, to win the opportunity to be one of National Geographic’s next great storytellers. The contest, presented by @MazdaUSA, runs through November 18, 2019.  Open to legal residents of the 50 US/DC only; 18+. For more information go to natgeo.com/mazdacontest.

Photo by Pete McBride @pedromcbride | Years ago I observed this lioness in the morning—anxious, skinny, weak, and desperate. I feared she might not make it. But later in the day, she caught the scent of a kudu, killed by wild dogs. Finding  inner strength, she bounded through the river, larger than life, fearlessly scaring off the pack, holding her ground with hyenas, and earning enough nourishment until her next meal. The cycle of life and will to survive amazes me. For more wild moments, follow @pedromcbride. #lion #botswana #Africa #wildlife

Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder | The bright lights of Las Vegas Boulevard shine at night. Today is World Cities Day. How will the cities of the future be powered? What will a renewable energy, carbon-free future look like? How can we get there? This photograph was made on Day 6 of an ongoing @natgeo renewable energy road trip across the USA #roadtripto2070 #WorldCitiesDay

Photo by Gabriele Galimberti @gabrielegalimbertiphoto and Juri De Luca | Fossils of long-extinct creatures aren’t just for museums. Today there’re in homes and businesses, as wealthy collectors indulge a controversial hobby. 
Known in some circles as the “dinosaur cowboy,” rancher Clayton Phipps (at top) explores part of the Hell Creek formation near his home in Jordan, Montana, with his son Luke. The layers of fossil-rich rock date to the end of the Cretaceous period and contain a valuable record of the world just before the dinosaurs became extinct. Many scientifically important fossils have been found here, including the world’s first identified T. rex, in 1902. In the United States, fossils found on private property usually belong to the landowner, and collectors may strike deals with owners to dig on their land. Phipps says fossils generate the bulk of his income, so when he’s not tending to ranch duties, he works his land in a more lucrative way—scouring it for dinosaur bones. #dinosaur #fossil #extinct #dinosaurs

Photo by Jennifer Hayes @JenniferHayesIG | An African elephant uses its trunk to blow bubbles as it rests on the bottom of a tannin-rich river in the Okavango Delta, Botswana. The elephants rolled about on the bottom, scratching their skin and pushed their tusks in and out of the soft sand until the ivory was polished to a rich creamy, white color. Watching these incredible, intelligent beings underwater is an emotional gift that stays with you long after you put the camera away. Despite an international ban on ivory trade the black market for ivory leads to the poaching of over 30,000 elephants a year.  for #MoreOcean follow @jenniferHayesIG. #Elephant #JOY #BlowingBubbles #OkavangoDelta

Photo by Thomas Peschak @thomaspeschak | When rations run short on Wolf Island, in the remote northern Galápagos, the sharp-beaked ground finches become vampires. Their sitting targets are the Nazca boobies and other large birds nesting on the plateau. Boobies thrive here, nesting among dense cactus thickets and fishing in the surrounding ocean, but the finches have a tougher time. The island has no permanent water and little rainfall. The finches–birds that inspired Darwin’s Theory of Evolution–rely on a scant diet of seeds and insects that regularly dries up. Pecking away at the base of booby flight feathers with their sharp beaks–a trait that may have evolved from feeding on the birds’ parasites–they drink blood to survive. For more photographs of vampire birds follow @thomaspeschak.

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | The first cave we worked in during our ongoing Greenland Caves Project expedition is called Crystal Palace. We had managed to climb into it on the 2015 expedition. Accessing it required several hundred meters of ascent up precarious scree slopes like these. For every two steps forward, we took one step back; everything moved underfoot. When we reached the top, the difficulties were not over. We then had to traverse a smaller but highly exposed scree slope to reach a narrow ledge, before accessing the cave. We protected ourselves across the exposed areas by installing a hand line and clipped into it.

Photos by Ian Teh @iantehphotography | I’m on the trail to discover how cardamom is harvested and used in Vietnamese culture. On this day I’m off to a region in Sapa that’s supposed to have some spectacular scenery—if only I could see it. Swipe to see more. 1. Traveling Vietnamese style, Lang has my suitcase between her legs, and I have my camera bag on my front, with camera in hand, plus a backpack. 2. The near-constant fog gave way to torrential rain today, hence the emergency poncho outfits. 3. The rain didn't relent so plan B was to have a Vietnamese coffee. Sure enough, the weather improved after I ordered. 4. The weather cleared a little, giving me a taste of what surrounded me. On assignment for @natgeo #onassignment #natgeo #vietnam #sapa #travel

caption: Photos by Babak Tafreshi @babaktafreshi | I was recently in Chile's Atacama Desert working on a project under an amazing sky, one of the darkest night skies on the planet. This is a telephoto close-up of the Southern Cross, the smallest constellation but the most iconic to Southern Hemisphere nations—it even appears on several countries' flags. The large dark nebula called Coalsack sits next to it. While details in this single three-minute exposure (on a star-tracking mount) go far beyond what can be seen by the  naked eye, swipe to the next photo, to a wide-angle view, with the cross location annotated. This shows what you can see under such a dark southern sky with your own eyes, but not the colors. Our eyes are almost colorblind at dark, but still we can see the Milky Way incredibly. Explore more of astronomy and space photography with me @babaktafreshi. ⁣#saveournightsky #southerncross #astrophotography #atacama #twanight
Photo by Jimmy Chin @jimmychin | Half Dome after a storm. For more images of wilderness landscapes around the world, follow @jimmychin

Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | //Supported by Nat Geo Society/Wyss Campaign for Nature committed to protecting 30% of the planet by 2030. // An ocelot triggers a camera trap as it walks across a tree that bridges a river in the rainforests of Costa Rica's Osa Peninsula. Ocelots hunt small mammals and birds in the forest, both on the ground and in the trees. Shot with the help of Andy Whitworth, David Garcia, and @osaconservation. #campaignfornature

caption: Photo by Brian Skerry @brianskerry | A large tiger shark with two hooks in its mouth swims over shallow-water sand flats in the northern Bahamas. Tiger sharks are apex predators living in tropical waters, and much of their lives remained a mystery until recently. Researchers are now learning about behaviors and migratory patterns that are beginning to fill in the puzzle of their life cycle. Despite being large predators, life in the ocean is difficult and they face many challenges to survive. As with all species, the tiger shark faces declining populations worldwide as the demand for shark fins continues. Having photographed sharks for more than three decades, it is more commonplace these days to see sharks with hooks. To see more sharks, whales, and other ocean animals, follow @brianskerry. #sharks #tigersharks #bahamas #predators

caption:
Photo by Tasneem Alsultan @TasneemAlsultan | "I can't define what type of marriage I had for 18 years, but I know I suffered. I finally understood that in order to receive my divorce, I had to give away my children. On my tearful return from dropping off my children to their father in a new city, I found that my home had been set on fire. I had lost everything. When the pain is too intense, you become numb..." These are the words of woman I'll call "N," who stands in the shell of her home. She plans to rebuild it. As part of my ongoing project Saudi Tales of Love, I've been documenting the lives of over 40 Saudi women across the country. I realize as a Saudi woman myself that there are obstacles that are unique to us as Saudi women, but I also have come to see how the more difficulties there are...the more strong and resilient we become. #women #saudiarabia

Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For a week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo were photographed by women, about women. Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Kristine Tompkins, photographed in Pumalin Park, Chile, February 7, 2019.
Kristine Tompkins is a conservationist and former CEO of Patagonia, Inc. In anticipation of the 100th anniversary of the 19th amendment, National Geographic is highlighting what it means to be female. As part of that coverage, we photographed luminaries from around the world. 
Check out the link in our bio to learn about Nat Geo’s groundbreaking new book that showcases an incredible group of history-making women. #NatGeoWomenofImpact

Photo by Diana Markosian @markosian | Girls in Chechnya eat a meal at their home. After nearly two decades of war and 70 years of Soviet rule, during which religious participation was banned, modern-day Chechnya is going through an Islamic revival.

Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For a week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo were photographed by women, about women. Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photos by Erin Trieb @erintrieb | In Afghanistan, women playing outdoor sports is highly uncommon, as it’s considered a "cultural shame" for women to be seen participating in a physical activity. However, since 2015 a team of Afghan female mountaineers—led by @afghan_ascend, a nonprofit developing young women into leaders through community service and the sport of mountain climbing—has been defying cultural boundaries and  challenging the gender stereotypes of Afghan society. Often, when these women climb outdoors, local boys will throw stones at them, and many of them have been threatened by their own family members for participating in the sport. 
In 2018 Ascend’s team attempted the unthinkable: to climb and summit the highest peak in Afghanistan, Mount Noshaq (24,580 feet), which had never been climbed by an Afghan woman. Hanifa, shown in the following photos, became her nation’s first woman to complete the historic feat. Says Hanifa: “I did this for every Afghan woman.” These images are part of the feature- length documentary film "An Uphill Battle," set to release in 2021. #girlsarealsostrong #Afghangirls #getoutside #forceofnature #sheexplores

Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For a week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo were photographed by women, about women. Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by Maggie Steber @maggiesteber | Robb and Alesia Stubblefield hug their 21-year-old daughter, Katie, at their apartment in the Ronald McDonald House in Cleveland, Ohio, in January 2018. Katie received a full face transplant in 2017. Robb and Alesia have been fierce, patient, and determined warriors for their daughter ever since she destroyed her face in a suicide attempt with a rifle several years ago. 
Quitting their full-time teaching jobs, they have gone above and beyond by becoming students of face transplants and the medications Katie is required to take. Determined to help Katie regain as normal and valuable a life as possible, they set their own lives on hold. Exhausted on all fronts, they have continued to be tireless warriors for their daughter as she undergoes surgeries to refine her face and improve her speech and vision. #ngwomenofvision #facetransplant #women

Photo by Hannah Reyes Morales @hannahreyesmorales | Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For the next week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo will be photographed by women, about women.

Eleven-year-old pro skateboarder Sky Brown skates in Venice Beach, California. "I want girls to know they can do anything they want," she says. She’s got her sights set on the Olympics. If she qualifies, she could match the record for the youngest athlete to compete in the Summer Olympics. 
For more stories, follow me @hannahreyesmorales. #girls

Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by Dina Litovsky @dina_litovsky | At ISEF 2019, Russian high school student Inna Larina looks through a viewing device she designed with teammate Nataliya Ivlieva. The wireless device allows blind and visually impaired people to navigate unfamiliar terrains by using sensors. ISEF, a prestigious International Science and Engineering Fair, attracts students
from around the world. Though young women have been a minority in STEM sciences in the past, this year’s fair was evenly split by gender, a huge jump from just 35% in 1960. The story on girls in science was shot for National Geographic’s November issue, "Women: A Century of Change." For more images follow me @dina_litovsky.

Photo by Maddie McGarvey @maddiemcgarvey | I met a woman with the most amazing silver hair while traveling through Oklahoma on a road trip out West. I was attending a Powwow in Carnegie, OK and she was nice enough to let me take her portrait. I’m always so thankful for the incredible people photography allows me to meet every single day. For more views from around the country, follow me @maddiemcgarvey.

Photos by Saumya Khandelwal @khandelwal_saumya | Since a horrifying assault shocked the nation, women in India have pressed for protection from harassment and abuse in public spaces. The gang rape of a woman in a moving bus in 2012 sparked nationwide protests, spurring the government to fast-track court hearings for the accused assailants and set up a fund for safety initiatives.

In these images, Usha Vishwakarma of Red Brigade Lucknow demonstrates self-defense techniques to girls in rural Rajasthan. 
Tarannum Shokat Ali, 28, is a bouncer in Cafe Mafioso in New Delhi, where her job is identify rogues and ensure a safe environment for women. She hopes every club will adopt the approach and encourages other young women to follow in her footsteps—even though her family doesn’t approve of her work.

Officers from the Kerala Pink Police Patrol respond to a man trespassing in a female-only accommodation in Thiruvananthapuram. The all-women units, which opened in the city in 2016 and include 32 officers, are called for reports that involve women and children, and they specialize in cases requiring counseling and arbitration. #women #womensafety #womenempowerment

Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For a week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo were photographed by women, about women. Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by Lynsey Addario @lynseyaddario | Danielle Kallmes, 19, pauses at the edge of the woods during the first morning of the Crucible, a 54-hour marathon of physical and emotional endurance. The Crucible tests what the marines have learned during their time training to become recruits to Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island in South Carolina, the only place in the United States where women become Marines.
For the next 11 weeks, these women would speak only in the third person, calling themselves “this recruit” instead of “I” to absolve all individuality. Today women make up 8 percent of the United States Marine Corps. 
To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.

Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman | Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For the next week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo will be photographed by women, about women.

Hussein and Suaad Ahmad live in Doha, Qatar — their new home after fleeing Raqqa, Syria and the chaos and violence of the Syrian war. They have six adult children who have ended up scattered across Europe and the Middle East as their family tried to find ways to rebuild their lives. The Ahmads are comparatively lucky — their nuclear family all escaped Syria safely — but I could feel very viscerally just how stressful it was for both of them to not know exactly where all of their children were in the world, and whether they were safe. For more of the Ahmads' story, from France to Qatar to Norway, head to @dzalcman and check out the latest pinned story on my profile.

Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

caption:
Photo by Amber Bracken @photobracken | Gwen Bourque untangles her horse's mane while riding in Buffalo Lake Métis Settlement, Alberta. Buffalo Lake is one of eight Alberta Métis settlements created in 1938 in response to activism by landless Métis, but it was largely unoccupied until 1951 because it was remote and difficult to access. To date, the settlements are the only constitutionally protected Métis land base in Canada. Métis are the descendants of European settlers and indigenous people but their culture is distinct from both groups. #metis #indigenousrights #horselife #outdoorwomen

Rachel Kahan nurses her daughter, Michaela, while nanny Annie Nabbie trims the child’s toenails. Nabbie immigrated �from Trinidad, and last year Kahan cosigned her green card application.
I spent five months embedded with New York City families, documenting the brutal math of caring for children in America.

Photo by Melissa Farlow @melissafarlow | It is a gift when people let you into their lives. I arrived on my first assignment in Africa to photograph women in various countries for a book project. My heart was open and I wanted to understand their cultures, which was challenging because my mind was shaped by Western values. 
Over the next couple of months, I lived with families in Ethiopia, Mali, and South Africa. After initial interviews with the women, I found it easier to photograph without a translator and to just to be with them. 
Their lives were not easy. I understood them more deeply as I fell into their patterns and rituals. They worked hard and valued cooperative relationships with other women. They were selfless and shared in common the desire to make their children’s lives better. I was touched by their caring manner and I admired their strength. 
I earned their trust. When photographing people I do not look for our differences, but how we are all the same. @thephotosociety @natgeofineart @natgeoimagecollection #ethiopia #africa #women

Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Sylvia Earle, pictured here in Dunedin, Florida, is an American marine biologist, explorer, author, and lecturer. She has been a National Geographic explorer-in-residence since 1998. Earle was the first female chief scientist of the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and was named by Time magazine as its first Hero for the Planet in 1998. She is also part of the group Ocean Elders, which is dedicated to protecting the ocean and its wildlife.

Check out the link in our bio to learn about Nat Geo’s groundbreaking new book that showcases an incredible group of history-making women. #NatGeoWomenofImpact

Cultural initiatives like Moni Dance have become all the more important amid Venezuela's ongoing crisis, where grassroots arts collectives create a space for normalcy and empowerment.

Photo by Stephanie Sinclair @stephsinclairpix | A student holds a small chalkboard while attending a school for girls in Pakistan. Every day girls face barriers to education caused by poverty, cultural norms and practices, poor infrastructure, violence, and fragility. But girls’ education goes beyond getting girls into school. It is also about ensuring that girls learn and feel safe while in school so they can complete all levels of education with the skills to effectively compete in the labor market. They must also learn the social-emotional and life skills necessary to navigate and adapt to a changing world; make decisions about their own lives; and contribute to their communities and the world. According to UNESCO estimates, 130 million girls between the ages of six and 17 are out of school and 15 million girls of primary school age—half of them in sub-Saharan Africa—will never enter a classroom. For more images, follow me @stephsinclairpix @tooyoungtowed. #letgirlslearn #girls #women #educationisaright

The Quran is taught to young Afghan girls at a refugee settlement on the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan. It is estimated that Pakistan hosts one of the largest refugee populations in the world, most of whom hail from Afghanistan. Officially, there are 1.4 million registered Afghan refugees, but according to most estimates, there are up to 1 million more undocumented refugees and migrants. Photo by Jodi Cobb @jodicobbphoto | Women around the world have inspired and humbled me almost every day of my nearly four decades as a National Geographic photographer. They’ve invited me into their worlds, opened their hearts to my curiosity and cameras, and shared their wisdom, stories, and strength. Ella Eronen, Finland’s most beloved actress who inspired her whole nation with her strength, is shown here at home in the costume of her most famous stage role in 1980. Behind her is her portrait in that role, painted by her husband. She died at age 87 in 1987.  Follow me @jodicobbphoto for more images of women and the world.

Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For a week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo were photographed by women, about women. Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by Camilla Ferrari @camillaferrariphoto | As time passed the light created an ever changing geometry on the walls of Panjiayuan market in Beijing, China. Objects appeared and disappeared from the stalls, where sellers gently and patiently waited for customers to approach. Sometimes a person would touch every single stone, almost in a meditative process, to find the perfect shape and the right texture. As the day went by, this woman, like a beautiful statue, stood waiting for the bargaining ceremony to start.

Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For a week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo were photographed by women, about women. Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by Beverly Joubert @beverlyjoubert | It's not easy picking out women who have shaped my life and inspired the paths that I've followed. There are many. While we try not to anthropomorphize animals, there are individuals whose determination, dedication, and apparent kindness—even in the face of dire circumstances—speak volumes. One such female is a lioness in the Okavango known as Fekeetsa, a name that translates to "overpower" or "overcome" because of the odds that she faced. 
Perhaps she resonates particularly with me because I spent so much time with her after Dereck Joubert and I had been badly injured by a buffalo. We learnt her story after months of our own recovery and my close call with death. Fekeetsa was left with a broken wrist after a buffalo hunt went wrong. It should have been a death sentence, but she had young cubs to feed and she wasn't going to give up on them. 
Despite undeniable pain, she changed her hunting strategy and searched the swamps for baby lechwe hidden in the reeds so she wouldn't have to chase them. Every day she went out with the excruciating injury, and every day she brought food back for her cubs, who grew stronger and bigger. Gradually she began to heal, although she will always limp. At the beginning of this year she even adopted a cub that had strayed from its own pride and gotten lost—a phenomenon that is unheard of among lions. 
Today Fekeetsa's cubs are nearing her size and she has recovered enough to broaden her hunts again. She has shown a spirit that I have seen in many women over the years—a knowledge that the responsibility lies with her and the complete refusal to accept failure.
#Fekeetsa #ThisismyTrophy

Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For a week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo were photographed by women, about women. Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by @jimrichardsonng // Sponsored by @IndigoAg // Soybeans in half-mile-long rows covered the rolling hills of Iowa last month. By now they have been harvested. Like many farmers in the American Midwest, Ben Riensche grows soybeans (in rotation with corn) because it is high-value protein and it is good for his soil. The legume, which came to Iowa from East Asia, is popular with farmers because it contributes to nitrogen fixation, thus reducing the need for artificial fertilizers. Ben also uses cover crops and no-till farming, all part of a complex farming system meant to preserve his farm’s fertility. // @IndigoAg is unlocking agriculture’s potential to help reverse climate change. That’s the vision behind the Terraton Initiative, a global movement with the goal of using regenerative farming practices to take one trillion tons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Follow @Terraton to see the progress.

Photo by Newsha Tavakolian | Negin, 28, sunbathes in the salty waters of the Caspian Sea. During Iran’s hot summers, many tourists travel up north to the cooler and green Caspian region. At public beaches, women can swim only while fully dressed, in accordance with Iran’s Islamic law. But there are also segregated beaches where they can wear outfits intended for the beach.

Photo by Acacia Johnson @acacia.johnson | Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For the next week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo will be photographed by women, about women.

Polar expedition guide Françoise Gervais plays her accordion on the stern of a ship near the Lemaire Channel in Antarctica. Originally from Quebec, Françoise is a deep-sea explorer, environmental conservation specialist, polar expedition leader, and cold-water diver—and one of the many remarkable women I've photographed as part of an ongoing series about women who work in Antarctica. “What I’ve realized over the years is that a lot of women don’t realize they can do things: go on expeditions, take leadership roles, or work in extreme environments," she says. "It’s not even in their subconscious. A lot of people don’t even consider guiding in the polar regions an option as a woman—and leading is a whole other story. You imagine Shackleton or Scott or Franklin. We keep hearing their names again and again. And we don’t even hear about the women.” Follow me @acacia.johnson for more stories from Antarctica and beyond. #antarctica #womeninantarctica #polar

Photo by Lynn Johnson @ljohnphoto | The November issue of National Geographic magazine discusses the state of women in the world today. Many women are rising up, fighting back, and succeeding in business and science. But this child, married at 13 years old, will remain invisible most of her life. She is flanked by her new husband and his best man. According to UNICEF, worldwide, one in three girls are married before the age of 15.

Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For a week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo were photographed by women, about women. Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by Ami Vitale @amivitale | Mary Lengees, one of the first female elephant keepers at Reteti Elephant Sanctuary in northern Kenya, caresses Suyian, the first resident. The dedicated keepers here provide round-the-clock care to the most vulnerable elephants to ensure the best outcomes, staying with them throughout the night. Mary is a trailblazer and an inspiration to me and to all who know her. She is one of the very first indigenous Samburu keepers in all of Africa. Although the idea of women working outside of the home is new here, the community has embraced the program. When the seven women keepers return to their homes, the people in their villages rush to them to hear news about the elephants in their care. 
Follow @amivitale and @r.e.s.c.u.e to get involved and support this crucial work.
@conservationorg @thephotosociety @natgeoimagecollection #protectelephants #elephants #stoppoaching #kenya #worthmorealive

Photo by Michaela Skovranova @mishkusk | My underwater journey began at Shelly Beach in Sydney, Australia. I remember seeing a group of women swim by and playfully dive under the sea, encouraging each other as they explored and pushed their own boundaries. I feel like this gentle encouragement and playfulness is a beautiful part of womanhood and it’s something I continue to explore in my personal work. 
#women #nature #underwater #Sydney #Australia

Photo by Stephen Alvarez @salvarezphoto // Sponsored by @salesforce // In the Tennessee River Gorge the eastern hardwood forest is the basis of a complex ecosystem that flourishes in a rapidly urbanizing part of the United States. The land is protected by the Tennessee River Gorge Trust, the state of Tennessee, and the Tennessee Valley Authority. A mature forest like this also acts as an effective carbon sink. In 2017 the Tennessee River Gorge Trust placed 6,000 acres of its land in the carbon offset market, locking up over 225,000 metric tons of carbon. // According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Special Report on Climate Change and Land, the loss of healthy forests is a key cause of climate change. In the lead-up to COP25, the next UN meeting on #climateaction, @unfoundation encourages you to spotlight solutions to climate change using the hashtag #EyeOnClimate.

Photo by Nora Lorek @noralorek | Lea Kadi, 67, can often be found selling coffee while seated in the shadow of her house. In South Sudan, she worked as a midwife for 35 years. Now, with a handful of customers in the neighborhood, she makes less than one dollar a week.

The civil war in South Sudan has displaced two million people. When refugees arrived to Uganda they carried their only possessions wrapped in milayas, embroidered sheets passed down for generations. Today in Bidibidi, the second largest refugee camp in the world, milayas are being sewn but there are few customers. Through the Milaya Project these women will be able to sell their art and transform their collectives into self-sufficient businesses. Follow @milayaproject for more information on how to support these women.

Photo by Karla Gachet @kchete77 | 
Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For the next week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo will be photographed by women, about women.

Omentoke Omene, 26, and her one- month-old baby girl go into the field to plant plantain and cut down some smaller trees, leaving room for the yuca (manioc) to grow. They are Huaorani from the community of Noneno, located along the Shiripuno River in the Amazon rainforest. Women are more likely to take care of their crops to feed their family. #amazonwomen

Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Alicia Garza photographed in Oakland, California, January 11, 2019. Alicia Garza is a civil rights activist, writer, and co-founded the Black Lives Matter movement. In anticipation of the 100th anniversary of the 19th amendment, National Geographic is highlighting what it means to be female. As part of that coverage we photographed luminaries from around the world.

Check out the link in our bio to learn about Nat Geo’s groundbreaking new book that showcases an incredible group of history-making women. #NatGeoWomenofImpact

Photo by Cristina Mittermeier @Mitty | When this sperm whale, an old matriarch judging by the many scars in her body, started slowly swimming away, I found myself riding the strong current she created with her massive fluke. She knew I was right behind her, but she didn't seem to mind. More than once I thought about touching her, but as a wildlife photographer it's critical to pass through these moments as little more than a shadow. This is their world. So instead of giving in to my urge, I kept my distance and kept up with her slow swim for as long as I could, and then watched until she eventually disappeared into the warm waters off Dominica. Follow me @Mitty for more from my expeditions with @SeaLegacy that have changed me as an artist and a conservationist. #WhaleTail #SpermWhale #UnderwaterPhotography #ExtinctionEndsHere

Nat Geo is celebrating women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. For a week, all of our posts and stories on @natgeo were photographed by women, about women. Use #NatGeoWomenofImpact to share how a woman in your life has empowered you.

Photo by Katie Orlinsky @katieorlinsky | The Nalukataq, or blanket toss, is a celebratory Inupiat tradition originating from when hunters would get launched into the air on what was (and still is) a giant trampoline made out of seal skins in order to catch a glimpse of distant prey. This traditional blanket toss was held at Point Hope, Alaska’s annual whaling feast celebration in 2015. 
For the people of Point Hope, nothing is more important than the bowhead whale. Their calendar year revolves around whaling, hunting, fishing, and gathering, a lifestyle Alaskans call subsistence, which is as much cultural tradition as dietary and economic necessity. This tradition is at risk as a result of climate change. Erosion and thawing permafrost are destroying ice cellars that store the meat while at the same time eating up the landscape, making travel and hunting increasingly dangerous on the fragile, shifting ground.

Photo by @jimrichardsonng // Sponsored by @IndigoAg // The corn harvest makes farmer Annie Dee happy. Driving her huge combine across her fields on the Dee River Ranch in Alabama, she gets to see the rewards coming back from a year of hard work. She watches a computer screen in the cab to see real-time yield data that shows how much corn she is harvesting—square foot by square foot—across her fields. That tells her how well she is doing at improving her soil by reducing erosion, encouraging earthworms, increasing water-holding capacity, and building soil organic matter. These things work together to help take carbon out of the atmosphere and sequester it in the soil. It’s all part of Annie’s life as a farmer. // @IndigoAg is unlocking agriculture’s potential to help reverse climate change. That’s the vision behind the Terraton Initiative, a global movement with the goal of using regenerative farming practices to take one trillion tons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Follow @Terraton to see the progress.

Photo by Maggie Steber @maggiesteber | Katie Stubblefield sits quietly on her hospital bed during a rare moment of solitude following a full face transplant at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio. Katie received the donation of a face in 2017, three years after losing her face during a suicide attempt with a rifle. Katie’s new face was donated by Sandra Bennington after her granddaughter, Adrea Schneider, fell into a coma from a drug overdose. 
During Katie's stay in the hospital, doctors stopped by frequently to check on her progress, sutures, and medications. Katie's face remained swollen several weeks after the surgery. This photo was taken for "The Story of a Face," published in National Geographic magazine in 2018. #natgeowomenofvision #facetransplant  #women

Photo by Hannah Reyes Morales @hannahreyesmorales | We are kicking off Women’s Week where we will be celebrating all the women who fearlessly push boundaries and inspire the next generation of changemakers. All of our posts and stories on @natgeo will be photographed by women, about women.

Marta, a survivor of assault, sits with her husband, Apolinar, in their home. Marta describes Apolinar’s support as instrumental to her healing.

Marta is part of the Malaya Lolas, a group of grandmothers in the Philippines who were collectively assaulted more than seven decades ago in a mass rape during the Second World War. In the absence of working structures to seek support and reparations, they came together, formed friendships, and rebuilt their town, which was reduced to ashes. "We aren’t strong enough to protest in the streets anymore," one of the grandmothers told me. "But we want to tell our story." I worked on this story more than a decade after my own grandmother told me about her trauma from the war. She cannot form sentences anymore, but it felt necessary to try to recall what she wanted to impart. These grandmothers—and my own—showed me that the stories we are told are living histories that we all have a part to play in writing. 
To see more from this project, "Roots From Ashes," follow me @hannahreyesmorales.
#Philippines #JSM2019 #worldpressphoto
